title: Data Protection: An Opportunity for Growth
displayTitle: Data Protection: An Opportunity for Growth
body:
Data protection is of paramount importance and this covers both market-sensitive data and personal data. Lloyd’s sees such regulations as an opportunity to streamline the delivery of data services, increase trust and deliver growth in the market.

In this lesson we’ll explore:

  • Why data protection regulations are an opportunity, not simply a compliance exercise
  • Streamlining the global transfer of data
  • Using standards to deliver compliance and efficiency
  • Opportunities to improve data management
  • Advantages of reducing unnecessary data and process duplication
  • How data protection regulations strengthen customer trust
  • Why respecting the rights of individuals is critical

title: Q8: Contacts for data protection enquiries
displayTitle: Contacts for data protection enquiries
body: If you have questions or concerns about data protection or require help to enable you to work with personal data what should you do?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Data Protection office should be your first point of contact for all GDPR enquiries. You can contact the DPO at data.protection@lloyds.com

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The Data Protection office should be your first point of contact for all GDPR enquiries. You can contact the DPO at data.protection@lloyds.com

title: Why data protection regulations are an opportunity, not simply a compliance exercise
displayTitle: Introduction
body:
Data protection is of paramount importance and this covers both market-sensitive data and personal data. Recent changes in data protection regulations – notably the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) – mean that organisations not only have increased compliance responsibilities, but they must also respect the individuals’ personal data rights.

Lloyd’s sees such regulations as an opportunity to streamline the delivery of data services, increase trust and deliver growth in the market. 

Moving away from loosely connected paper systems to streamlined digital services leads to benefits such as a significant reduction in audits for coverholders. Such systems include growth-focused common standards and data management practices that also encapsulate regulation compliance. Lloyd's sees data protection as an opportunity to drive best practices in handling of all data – why take the risk of using outdated practices?

title: Streamlining the global transfer of data
displayTitle: Streamlining the global transfer of data
body:
One key aspect of the new data protection regulations is the increased clarity determining with whom data can be shared. The GDPR also provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EEA. 

Transfers outside of the EEA (including to another Lloyd's office) may only be made:

  • to locations that the European Commission decide provide an adequate level of protection
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is provided through contractual clauses

title: How data protection regulations strengthen customer trust
displayTitle: How data protection regulations strengthen customer trust
body:
Research from the Information Commissioner's Office, the UK's independent body set up to uphold information rights, found that only 20% of the UK public have trust and confidence in companies and organisations storing personal information. 

A more detailed study by the Open Data Institute found that within the commercial sector, 57% of consumers trust banks with personal information while only 22% trust online retailers. One third (33%) of respondents said clearer explanation about how personal data is used would make them feel more comfortable . 

Lloyd’s has already taken key steps to not only improve privacy notices, but to take a lead in ensuring that they are clear for everyone to read and understand, such as the Lloyd’s Bridge platform privacy notice.

title: Is data protection an opportunity for growth for you?
displayTitle: Is data protection an opportunity for growth for you?
body: Take the quiz and test your knowledge

title: Advantages of reducing unnecessary data and process duplication
displayTitle: Advantages of reducing unnecessary data and process duplication
body:
Under the GDPR 'Privacy by design' is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider people’s privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolt it on at the end. One of the main 'privacy by design’ principles is that of data minimisation. This helps ensure that only data absolutely necessary for the delivery of a service is collected and maintained.

Adopting a data minimisation approach will help the market eliminate duplication of process and data, while optimising the collection and retention policies that ensure risk is minimised. A focus on data minimisation can lead to faster innovation through lack of distraction caused by irrelevant data. 

The Delegated Authority Submission, Access and Transformation Services (DA SATS) platform uses premium, claim and risk data which it then transforms and validates before distribution to managing agents. This process brings consistent data to the market and removes the inefficiencies and problems around collection and retention policies inherent in spreadsheet-based systems.

title: Q5: Advantages of reducing unnecessary data and process duplication
displayTitle: Advantages of reducing unnecessary data and process duplication
body: Which of the following can help reduce impact of data breaches?

_items.text: Deleting data that is no longer required

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

New ‘privacy by design’ principles are designed to ensure that only data absolutely necessary for the delivery of a service is collected and maintained. 

Adopting a data minimisation approach will help the market eliminate duplication of process and data, while optimising the collection and retention policies that ensure risk is minimised. 

The Delegated Authority Submission, Access and Transformation Services (DA SATS) platform uses premium, claim and risk data which it then transforms and validates before distribution to managing agents. This process brings consistent data to the market and removes the inefficiencies and problems around collection and retention policies inherent in spreadsheet-based systems.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

New ‘privacy by design’ principles are designed to ensure that only data absolutely necessary for the delivery of a service is collected and maintained. 

Adopting a data minimisation approach will help the market eliminate duplication of process and data, while optimising the collection and retention policies that ensure risk is minimised. 

The Delegated Authority Submission, Access and Transformation Services (DA SATS) platform uses premium, claim and risk data which it then transforms and validates before distribution to managing agents. This process brings consistent data to the market and removes the inefficiencies and problems around collection and retention policies inherent in spreadsheet-based systems.

title: Q7: Why respecting the rights of individuals is critical
displayTitle: Why respecting the rights of individuals is critical
body: A significant change in recent data protection regulations has been the introduction of rights that individuals have over personal data. Depending on the basis for processing, which of the following rights do people who entrust personal data to us have?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The most significant change in recent data protection regulations has been the introduction of the rights that individuals have over personal data. 

Depending on the basis for processing, individuals have the right to rectify, restrict processing or transfer personal data held by Lloyd’s and the marketplace.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The most significant change in recent data protection regulations has been the introduction of the rights that individuals have over personal data. 

Depending on the basis for processing, individuals have the right to rectify, restrict processing or transfer personal data held by Lloyd’s and the marketplace.

title: Why respecting the rights of individuals is critical
displayTitle: Why respecting the rights of individuals is critical
body:
The most significant change in recent data protection regulations has been the introduction of the rights that individuals have over personal data that they entrust to us.

Depending on the basis for processing, individuals have the right to rectify, restrict processing or transfer personal data held by Lloyd’s and the marketplace. 

Through streamlining the processing of data within the market, such rights can be upheld easily with minimal impact on day-to-day operations. In fact the right to data transfer provides increased opportunities for the market to obtain data directly from customers through a direct transfer from another provider.

Insurance isn’t the first industry to harness the opportunity presented by increased portability and common standards. In the banking sector the Open Banking initiative is helping customers gain access to new products and services that are tailored specifically to their needs.

title: Component title
displayTitle: Component title

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: Using standards to deliver compliance and efficiency
displayTitle: Using standards to deliver compliance and efficiency
body:
New data protection regulations promote the use of common standards for data exchange. Lloyd’s is already pushing forward activities that define standards and agree formats for data exchange, not just with customers, but also within the market. 

While previously sharing and exchanging data was associated with significant time and resource, the Market Business Glossary provides an efficient alternative and already contains a number of key standards related to premiums, claims and risks that can be freely used by anyone in the Delegated Authority. 

This will enable the faster and more accurate exchange of data across the market, leading to huge efficiencies and common approaches to data protection.

title: Test your knowledge of how data protection provides an opportunity for growth
displayTitle: Test your knowledge of how data protection provides an opportunity for growth
body:
Is data protection an opportunity for growth for you?

Please scroll down to progress through the quiz questions. Feedback will appear indicating if you have chosen the right answer.

To pass you need to get 80% right (6/8). You will be advised if you have passed or failed once you have completed the questions.

Warning: Do not leave your assessment session as you will not be able to resume your assessment.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: Opportunities to improve data management
displayTitle: Opportunities to improve data management
body:
Like many industries, insurance is data rich, but much of this data is on paper or in non-standard spreadsheets that are emailed across organisations. An obvious risk here is accidental data breach: paper or electronic copies may inadvertently reach unintended recipients. 

Lloyd’s sees this as an opportunity to futureproof data management and IT of all data: to improve quality; standardise the collection and usage principles; at the same time as reducing the costs associated with storing only the data required to deliver value. 

For example, Placing Platform Limited’s electronic placing platform enables brokers and underwriters to quote, negotiate, bind and endorse business digitally, all in one place. This straight-through processing removes paper from the process, increases efficiency, reduces risk and improves customer service.

title: Q2: Streamlining the global transfer of data
displayTitle: Streamlining the global transfer of data
body: Which countries can an individual’s personal data be transferred to in order to provide requested services?

_items.text: Any EEA country and any third country approved by the European Commission that offers an adequate level of data protection.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Transfers outside of the EEA (including to another Lloyd's office) may only be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

body: New data protection regulations promote the use of common standards for data exchange. What should you do to ensure your data uses common standards?

While previously sharing and exchanging data was associated with significant time and resource, the Market Business Glossary provides an efficient alternative and already contains a number of key standards related to premiums, claims and risks that can be freely used by anyone in the Delegated Authority.

title: Q6: How data protection regulations strengthen customer trust
displayTitle: How data protection regulations strengthen trust
body:
The privacy notice is a key part of new data protection regulations.

It should be...

_items.text: vague, allowing free use of personal data
clear for everyone to read and understand

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A privacy notice should be clear for everyone to read and understand. Lloyd’s has already taken key steps to improve privacy notices such as the Lloyd’s Bridge platform privacy notice.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

A privacy notice should be clear for everyone to read and understand. Lloyd’s has already taken key steps to improve privacy notices such as the Lloyd’s Bridge platform privacy notice.
